current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To establish a partnership between States that produce
		  energy onshore and offshore for our country with the Federal
		  Government.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Energy and Natural
			 Resources

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following bill; which
			 was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Fixing America's Inequities with
			 Revenues Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended to read as follows:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Section 9 of the Outer Continental Shelf
			 Lands Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act/s:9

header.#text:
Distribution of
			 revenues to coastal States

term.#tail:
means energy derived from a wind,
				solar, or ocean (including tidal, wave, and current) source.

means a county-equivalent
				subdivision of a coastal State all or part of which—

text.#text: lies within the coastal zone (as defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 304 of the Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Coastal Zone Management Act of 1972/s:304

text.#text:
the closest point of which is not more than
				200 nautical miles from the geographical center of any leased tract.

term.#tail:
means a State with a
				coastal seaward boundary within 200 nautical miles distance of the geographical
				center of a leased tract in an outer Continental Shelf region adjacent to the
				State.

does not include a coastal State, the majority
				of the coastline of which is subject to a leasing moratorium.

mean minimum great
				circle distance and distances, respectively.

means a tract or other
				area leased or made available for the exploration, development, or production
				of oil, natural gas, or alternative or renewable energy.

means any
				State or Federal prohibition on the development of oil, natural gas, and
				alternative and renewable energy sources, including preleasing, leasing, and
				related activities, on the outer Continental Shelf.

text.#text:
the Alaska outer
				Continental Shelf region;

the Gulf of
				Mexico outer Continental Shelf region; or

the Pacific outer
				Continental Shelf region.

term.#tail: means the Secretary of the Interior.

header.#text:
Coastal State
				revenue sharing for outer Continental Shelf energy sources

text.#text:
Subject to the other provisions of this section, for
				fiscal year 2014 and each subsequent fiscal year—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall deposit in a special account in the Treasury, 37.5 percent
				of all revenues derived from all rentals, royalties, bonus bids, and other sums
				due and payable to the United States from the development of oil, natural gas,
				and alternative and renewable energy on the outer Continental Shelf; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act/s:9/ss:b

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to coastal States and coastal
				political subdivisions; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act/s:9/ss:b/p:1/sp:A

27.5 percent of
				the revenues described in

10 percent of
				the revenues to coastal States that establish funds in the treasuries of the
				coastal States to support projects and activities relating to alternative or
				renewable energy, energy research and development, energy efficiency, or
				conservation.

from any lease shall be allocated to
				each coastal State in amounts (based on a formula established by the

by regulation) that are inversely proportional to the respective distances
				between the point on the coastline of each coastal State that is closest to the
				geographic center of the applicable leased tract and the geographic center of
				the leased tract.

text.#text:
The
				allocable share of a coastal State is limited to the revenues collected from a
				leased tract located no more than 200 nautical miles from the coastline of the
				coastal State and within the outer Continental Shelf region of the coastal
				State.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall pay 25 percent of the allocable share
				of each coastal State, as determined under

, to the coastal
				political subdivisions of the coastal State.

to coastal political subdivisions shall be
				allocated to each coastal political subdivision in accordance with

by
				regulation) that are inversely proportional to the respective distances between
				the point in each coastal political subdivision that is closest to the
				geographic center of the applicable leased tract and the geographic center of
				the leased tract; and

90 percent shall
				be allocated in amounts (based on a formula established by the

10 percent shall

header.#text:
Revenue sharing
			 for certain onshore energy sources

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall
				disburse 50 percent of all revenues derived from all rentals, operating fees,
				royalties, bonus bids, rights-of-way, and other amounts due and payable to the
				United States from the development of alternative or renewable onshore energy
				sources to the State within the boundaries of which the energy source is
				located.

This Act and the
			 amendments made by this Act take effect on October 1, 2013.
